channel.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
channel.description:
Today I began renaming the client and it occured to me that many people have passed this way before. Basically anyone who has posted a tut or info on a part of the client knows what is going on in that section and rename methods/vars to suit. What annoys me is that people have spent time on this and then other people (like me) have had to do their work all over again, wasting time. It seems obvious that we need to cooperate to actually build something really good.
Okay this probably won't happen overnight but I would like everyone to contribute to the renaming of the client. To get an idea on what needs to be done to increase cooperation, could you please post, [b]stating what it would require and under what conditions to get you to release your knowledge to the community.[/b]
Hopefully this will allow us to speed up development times of anything you can think of with regards to hacking the client.

item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

Okay, been talking on irc. with regards to “licensing”:

[ul][li]Ruler dosn’t like gpl but he will contribute so whatever.[/li]
[li]We can hardly gpl jagex’s client.[/li]
[li]Even if we did we can hardly control it.[/li][/ul]

This brings into question about wether we can put this on sourceforge.

Read full topic

item.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

He can “steal” it, providing he works on it and contributes to the project then anyone of us can use it.
If this is too work everyone needs to put their personal conflicts with others aside and work together as a team for once. There is no point in doing this if there will be alot of friction in the group. As I just said to PSB on MSN if your a team you will be better motivated and are more likely of finishing the task. Once it is finished the team achievement and effort feels more rewarding than that of an individual once. This is why most tasks people set out to do along rarely get finished - look at these boards for numerous examples :

If this is to work we need to pull together now and just get on with the job. People influencing negativity in the group can simply be kicked off. If we want to do this then it can be done. Note the keywords

Read full topic

item.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

pplsuqbawlz:

A lack of idiots able to commit to the svn. I can’t handle working on projects where other developer’s actually make the project head backwards in time. Mind you, I’m completely surprised this is even possible, but just ask Ollie, he can manage it.

lol you wernt joking when you said you were in a bad mood

Read full topic

item.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

I believe Private servers will move forward once the “next generation” of “child java programmers” come through. You see, at the moment the only people who can program well enough and efficiently do not play the game and therefore have no need for private servers… once we got some kids who can play the game and code… then the they will move forward but for now. Yes, I agree - they are pretty much moving backwards with tutorial rippers releasing old code every coming day.

More on-topic. I’ll help with this once the SVN is up it seems like an interesting project. Although we’d have to be very organized with documentation and what not.

Read full topic

pplsuqbawlz:

A lack of idiots able to commit to the svn. I can’t handle working on projects where other developer’s actually make the project head backwards in time. Mind you, I’m completely surprised this is even possible, but just ask Ollie, he can manage it.

sounds good, one would not like a plentiful supply of idiots to commit. If it was my project i would prefer no idiots.

As for a project heading backwards, the only project that sounds like it is going backwards is private servers. I see projects going forward, scar, ibot, arga, even cherokee are all moving forward.

Read full topic

item.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

frank_:

to be perfectly honestly, you cannot learn the client unless you rename stuff yourself

It certainly speeds things up if you can follow other people’s work rather than having to figure it entirly out for your self. Hence the commenting.

Krichevskoy: I like the idea of heavy commenting. As you can see from my cleaner most of the ~ fuckery can be removed as well as ugly shifts. We need to have a vote and see which client version is most popular (preferbly a relatively recent one - too old and it is useless).

Maybe mopar can provide svn? If not I know of a free svn server (if i can remember the name of it - i will just give me time) and we can use that. With regards to SVN, do we make it world readable? Who gets write access? If mopar joins in we might be able to tie it to mitb accounts and so make things a bit easier with regards to access permisions.

Naming conventions will be whoever gets there first (with something sensible of course). If there is a problem with it duke it out in the forums.

Found the link: http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/CommercialServices
Not sure which one to choose. If no one cares I will be using https://opensvn.csie.org/ because I used it before.

Read full topic

item.title: Cooperation in the MITB Community
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

Someone needs to send me a DVD burner and some discs so I can back up my primary hard drive and use it without worrying too much about the impending crash.
[/kidding]

First, we need to decide on a single version of the client to use. I suggest a version from before the additional obfuscations (inverse conditionals, awkward shifts, etc). This is partially because that’s a pain in the ass to read and the last thing we want is to screw up the client trying to fix it, and partially because all of my renaming has been done on a client from 16 May 2006.

We would also need to agree on a standard naming convention. What I for some reason called “ObjectWrapper” (an example of a bad name) is psb’s “DataHandler”

It’s not a necessity, but I would suggest that in addition to a renamed source submission, a you are also required to write a brief explanation/walkthrough explaining the functions of the code you’re documenting and how you identified it. This would allow people to double-check and to learn how to trace for themselves.

Another good measure might be carefully choosing the people with submit access. What’s the use of renaming if you rename it incorrectly?

Read full topic
